xml.subDomain: Know number names and the count sequence.
xml.minorDomain: Count to 100 by ones and tens.
xml.competency: Count by ones.
Count by tens.
Count by tens and ones.
Count within 5.
Count within 10.
Count within 20.
Count within 30.
Count within 50.
Count within 100.
Count backward starting at a given number.
xml.minorDomain: Count forward from a given number.
xml.competency: Count forward starting at 1.
Count forward starting at a given number.
Write the number 0.
Write the number 1.
Write the number 2.
Write the number 3.
Write the number 4.
Write the number 5.
Write the number 6.
Write the number 7.
Write the number 8.
Write the number 9.
Write the number 10.
Write the number 11.
Write the number 12.
Write the number 13.
Write the number 14.
Write the number 15.
Write the number 16.
Write the number 17.
Write the number 18.
Write the number 19.
Write the number 20.
Represent a number of objects with a written numeral 0-20.
xml.subDomain: Count to tell the number of objects.
xml.minorDomain: Understand the relationship between numbers and quantities.
xml.competency: Count 1 object.
Count 2 objects.
Count 3 objects.
Count 4 objects.
Count 5 objects.
Count 6 objects.
Count 7 objects.
Count 8 objects.
Count 9 objects.
Count 10 objects.
Count 11 objects.
Count 12 objects.
Count 13 objects.
Count 14 objects.
Count 15 objects.
Count 16 objects.
Count 17 objects.
Count 18 objects.
Count 19 objects.
Count 20 objects.
Count objects using a one-to-one correspondence.
xml.minorDomain: Count to tell how many for up to 20 objects.
xml.competency: Count objects arranged in a line.
Count objects arranged in a rectangular array.
Count objects arranged in a circle.
xml.minorDomain: Count to tell how many for up to 10 objects.
xml.competency: Count objects in a scattered configuration.
xml.minorDomain: Count out a given number of objects.
xml.competency: Given a number 1-20, count out that many objects.
Tell whether the number of objects in one group is equal or not equal to the number of objects in another group.
Match objects from two groups of up to 5 objects to compare.
Match objects from two groups of up to 10 objects to compare.
Tell whether the number of objects in one group is greater than, less than, or equal to the number of objects in another group.
Count to compare two groups of up to 5 objects.
Count to compare two groups of up to 10 objects.
Count to compare two groups of up to 20 objects.
Compare two written numerals up to 5.
Compare two written numerals up to 10.
Order up to 5 numbers within 5.
Order up to 4 numbers within 10.
Order up to 4 numbers within 20.
xml.subDomain: Understand addition as putting together and adding to.
xml.competency: Represent addition with objects, fingers, drawings, sounds, or actions.
Represent addition with a number bond.
Represent addition with a ten frame.
Represent addition with a sentence.
Represent addition with an expression.
Represent addition with an equation.
Identify the parts and the whole for a representation of numbers to 5.
Identify the parts and the whole for a representation of the number 6.
Identify the parts and the whole for a representation of the number 7.
Identify the parts and the whole for a representation of the number 8.
Identify the parts and the whole for a representation of the number 9.
Identify the parts and the whole for a representation of the number 10.
Use a number bond to represent numbers to 5.
Use a number bond to represent the number 6.
Use a number bond to represent the number 7.
Use a number bond to represent the number 8.
Use a number bond to represent the number 9.
Use a number bond to represent the number 10.
Identify the partner number to 5 that makes a given whole number 6-10.
Use a ten frame to represent numbers 6-10.
Solve add to addition word problems.
Solve put together addition word problems.
Identify the starting number and number being added in an add to addition word problem.
Identify the numbers being added in a put together addition word problem.
Add two numbers within a sum of 5.
Add two numbers within a sum of 10.
Use a group of 5 to add within 10.
Given a one-digit number, identify the missing number that makes a sum of 10.
Given a number 10 or less, identify two numbers that sum to the given number.
Identify patterns when adding 0.
Identify patterns when adding 1.
xml.subDomain: Understand subtraction as taking apart and taking from.
xml.competency: Represent subtraction with objects, fingers, drawings, sounds, or actions.
Represent subtraction with a number bond.
Represent subtraction with a ten frame.
Represent subtraction with a sentence.
Represent subtraction with an expression.
Represent subtraction with an equation.
Solve take from subtraction word problems.
Solve take apart subtraction word problems.
Identify the starting number and number being subtracted in a take from subtraction word problem.
Identify the whole and the parts in a take apart subtraction word problem.
Subtract two numbers within 5.
Subtract two numbers within 10.
Use a group of 5 to subtract within 10.
Identify patterns when subtracting 0.
Identify patterns when subtracting 1.
Identify patterns when subtracting all.
Tell whether a word problem represents addition or subtraction.
Write related addition and subtraction facts.
xml.Domain: Numbers and Operations in Base Ten
xml.subDomain: Work with numbers 11-19 to gain foundations for place value.
xml.competency: Represent the number 11 as 10 ones and 1 one.
Represent the number 11 using ten frames.
Represent the number 11 as an equation, 11 = 10 + 1.
Represent the number 12 as 10 ones and 2 ones.
Represent the number 12 using ten frames.
Represent the number 12 as an equation, 12 = 10 + 2.
Represent the number 13 as 10 ones and 3 ones.
Represent the number 13 using ten frames.
Represent the number 13 as an equation, 13 = 10 + 3.
Represent the number 14 as 10 ones and 4 ones.
Represent the number 14 using ten frames.
Represent the number 14 as an equation, 14 = 10 + 4.
Represent the number 15 as 10 ones and 5 ones.
Represent the number 15 using ten frames.
Represent the number 15 as an equation, 15 = 10 + 5.
Represent the number 16 as 10 ones and 6 ones.
Represent the number 16 using ten frames.
Represent the number 16 as an equation, 16 = 10 + 6.
Represent the number 17 as 10 ones and 7 ones.
Represent the number 17 using ten frames.
Represent the number 17 as an equation, 17 = 10 + 7.
Represent the number 18 as 10 ones and 8 ones.
Represent the number 18 using ten frames.
Represent the number 18 as an equation, 18 = 10 + 8.
Represent the number 19 as 10 ones and 9 ones.
Represent the number 19 using ten frames.
Represent the number 19 as an equation, 19 = 10 + 9.
xml.minorDomain: Compare the heights of two objects.
xml.competency: Tell when one object is taller than another object.
Tell when one object is shorter (in height) than another object.
Tell when two objects are the same height.
xml.minorDomain: Compare the lengths of two objects.
xml.competency: Tell when one object is longer than another object.
Tell when one object is shorter (in length) than another object.
Tell when two objects are the same length.
Use a tool (linking cubes) to compare lengths.
xml.minorDomain: Compare the weights of two objects.
xml.competency: Tell when one object is heavier than another object.
Tell when one object is lighter than another object.
Tell when two objects are the same weight.
Use a tool (linking cubes) to compare weights.
Use a tool (balance scale) to compare weights.
xml.minorDomain: Compare the compacities of two objects.
xml.competency: Tell when one object holds more than another object.
Tell when one object holds less than another object.
Tell when two objects hold the same amount.
Identify when the length or height of an object can be measured.
Identify when the weight of an object can be measured.
Identify when the capacity of an object can be measured.
Identify all of the measureable attributes of an object.
xml.subDomain: Classify objects and count the number of objects in each category.
xml.competency: Identify objects that belong to a given category.
Identify objects that do not belong to a given category.
Count the number of objects (up to 10) in a given category.
Compare the number of objects in two categories.
Identify a triangle.
Identify a rectangle.
Identify a square.
Identify a hexagon.
Identify a circle.
Describe features of a triangle (3 sides and 3 vertices).
Describe features of a rectangle(4 sides and 4 L-shaped vertices).
Describe features of a square (4 sides of equal length and 4 L-shaped vertices).
Describe features of a hexagon (6 sides and 6 vertices).
Describe features of a circle (has curved sides/no straight sides and no vertices).
Identify a cube.
Identify a sphere.
Identify a cone.
Identify a cylinder.
Describe features of a cube (has flat, square surfaces).
Describe features of a sphere (has a curved surfac/no flat surfaces).
Describe features of a cone (has a curved surface, a flat surface, and a vertex).
Describe features of a cylinder (has a curved surface and two flat surfaces).
xml.minorDomain: Distinguish between two- and three-dimensional shapes.
xml.competency: Identify two-dimensional shapes (flat).
Identify three-dimensional shapes (solid).
xml.minorDomain: Describe positions of objects in the enviroment.
xml.competency: Describe the position of an object as being above or below another object.
Describe the position of an object as being in front of or behind another object.
Describe the position of an object as being beside or next to another object.
xml.subDomain: Analyze, compare, create, and compose shapes.
xml.competency: Describe the sides of two-dimensional shapes (curved or straight).
Compare the number of sides of two-dimensional shapes.
Compare the number of vertices of two-dimensional shapes.
Identify three-dimensional shapes that roll (curved surface).
Identify three-dimensional shapes that stack (multiple flat surfaces).
Identify three-dimensional shapes that slide (flat surface).
Combine two-dimensional shapes to form a larger shape.
Use materials (sticks and clay balls) to create two-dimensional shapes.
Draw two-dimensionals shapes.
Combine three-dimensional shapes to form a larger shape.
Use materials (sticks and clay balls) to create three-dimensional shapes.
